recipe_title: The Best Buttermilk-Brined Southern Fried Chicken Recipe

conversation.utterance: Hey there! Happy to have you on board for our masterclass :) Today you will be learning how to prepare Southern Fried Chicken. Make sure you have all the ingredients and tools and feel free to ask questions. If you are ready to start cooking simply say start.

Alright so this is what you need to do first:

Combine the paprika, black pepper, garlic powder, oregano, and cayenne in a small bowl and mix thoroughly with a fork.

Step 2:  Whisk the buttermilk, egg, 1 tablespoon salt, and 2 tablespoons of the spice mixture in a large bowl. Add the chicken pieces and toss and turn to coat. Transfer the contents of the bowl to a gallon-sized zipper-lock freezer bag and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, and up to overnight, flipping the bag occasionally to redistribute the contents and coat the chicken evenly.

I'm sorry, I do not think I have this information. But manual whisking should be enough here.
Ok, after the 4 hours, what do I do?
Also be aware of the chemical processes that are going on in this step which is called brining.
Brining is the process by which a lean meat (most often chicken, turkey, or pork) is submerged in a saltwater solution.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Brining is the process by which a lean meat (most often chicken, turkey, or pork) is submerged in a saltwater solution.

conversation.utterance: That's very interesting, what does brining do
I'm happy to tell you this.

As the meat sits, the saltwater will slowly dissolve key muscle proteins—most notably myosin, a protein that acts as a sort of glue, holding muscle fibers together). As the myosin dissolves, three things take place:

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: As the meat sits, the saltwater will slowly dissolve key muscle proteins—most notably myosin, a protein that acts as a sort of glue, holding muscle fibers together).

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: As the myosin dissolves, three things take place:

conversation.utterance: First, the ability of the meat to hold onto moisture increases.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: First, the ability of the meat to hold onto moisture increases.

conversation.utterance: Second, brining alters the texture of the meat by allowing dissolved proteins to cross-link with each other. This is the main principle behind sausage making—dissolved proteins can bond with each other, creating a pleasantly bouncy, tender texture.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Second, brining alters the texture of the meat by allowing dissolved proteins to cross-link with each other.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: This is the main principle behind sausage making—dissolved proteins can bond with each other, creating a pleasantly bouncy, tender texture.

conversation.utterance: Third, as the brine slowly works its way into the meat, it seasons it beyond just the very surface. An overnight brine will penetrate a few millimeters into the meat, giving you built-in seasoning before you ever get to the breading.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Third, as the brine slowly works its way into the meat, it seasons it beyond just the very surface.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: An overnight brine will penetrate a few millimeters into the meat, giving you built-in seasoning before you ever get to the breading.

conversation.utterance: You can also spot a visual difference between unbrined and brined meat
Also: Using buttermilk affects the outcome in a special way :)

If you replace water with buttermilk, not only does the chicken come out just as moist as with water brine, it is actually significantly more tender as well, due to the tenderizing effects of buttermilk on food (soaking it for more than one night led to chicken that was so tender that it bordered on mush). Finally, hitting the buttermilk with spices helps build flavor right into the surface of the bird.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab

conversation.utterance: So these are the key features you should know about brining.  Was it helpful? Do you need more information?
If you wish to go to the next step, simply say "Next".

Step 3:  Whisk together the flour, cornstarch, baking powder, 2 teaspoons salt, and the remaining spice mixture in a large bowl. Add 3 tablespoons of the marinade from the zipper-lock bag and work it into the flour with your fingertips. Remove one piece of chicken from the bag, allowing excess buttermilk to drip off, drop the chicken into the flour mixture, and toss to coat. Continue adding chicken pieces to the flour mixture one at a time until they are all in the bowl. Toss the chicken until every piece is thoroughly coated, pressing with your hands to get the flour to adhere in a thick layer.

conversation.utterance: How can I help you with this step?
The ingredients we are using for the breading here, affect the result and crispiness of the crust in an interesting way.

Knowing that gluten—the network of proteins formed when flour meets water—is the most likely culprit that leads to a crust with an almost rock-like density.  First and foremost: cut the protein-rich wheat flour with cornstarch, a pure starch that adds moisture-absorbing capabilities to the breading without adding excess protein.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Knowing that gluten—the network of proteins formed when flour meets water—was the most likely culprit, I sought out ways to minimize its formation.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: My crust was certainly thick enough now, but I ran into another problem: rather than crisp and crunchy, it was bordering on tough, almost rock-like in its density.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: First and foremost: cut the protein-rich wheat flour with cornstarch, a pure starch that adds moisture-absorbing capabilities to the breading without adding excess protein.

conversation.utterance: Oh it is! Also baking powder is the second influencing factor!

Adding a couple teaspoons of baking powder to the mix helps bring a bit of air to the mix, forming a crust that is lighter and crisper, with increased surface area (and we all know that more surface area = more crispness, right?).

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Adding a couple teaspoons of baking powder to the mix helped bring a bit of air to the mix, forming a crust that was lighter and crisper, with increased surface area (and we all know that more surface area = more crispness, right?).

conversation.utterance: The reason is: baking powder raises the pH of the skin, causing it to brown more efficiently and the thin film of protein-rich liquid around it to form microbubbles that can add crispness.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: The salt acts as a brine, while the baking powder raises the pH of the skin, causing it to brown more efficiently and the thin film of protein-rich liquid around it to form microbubbles that can add crispness.

conversation.utterance: So that's the magic behind baking powder :-D
Do you want to hear another trick about how to make an extra-caggy coat?

Once the chicken was breaded, the later batches always come out better than the earlier ones as bits of the flour mixture clump together, making for an extra-craggy coat.  Adding a couple tablespoons of buttermilk to the breading mix and working it in with your fingertips before dredging the chicken simulates this effect nicely.

Buttermilk is a fermented dairy drink. Traditionally, it was the liquid left behind after churning butter out of cultured cream. However, most modern buttermilk is cultured. It is common in warm climates (including the Balkans, South Asia, the Middle East and the Southern United States) where unrefrigerated fresh milk sours quickly. Buttermilk can be drunk straight, and it can also be used in cooking. In making Soda bread, the acid in buttermilk reacts with the raising agent, sodium bicarbonate, to produce carbon dioxide which acts as the leavening agent. Buttermilk is also used in marination, especially of chicken and pork, which the lactic acid helps to tenderize, retain moisture and allows added flavors to permeate the meat.

provenance.page_title: Buttermilk

conversation.utterance: Was it helpful? Or do you want to hear more?

Buttermilk is the byproduct of butter making.
Butter is made by agitating cream resulting in clumps of fat and a milky white liquid that contains nearly no fat and some protein. If the cream was soured before (either by aging or by inoculating the cream with lactobacillae), the buttermilk will also be sour. If the butter was made from unfermented cream, the buttermilk will be mild.
Uncultured buttermilk is rarely sold, even if butter is made commercially with regular cream, the resulting buttermilk is soured afterwards.
As buttermilk is made from a fraction of whole milk (the cream), you could say it’s a part of soured milk. I outlined the process of butter making in this answer, that should also help understanding buttermilk.

provenance.page_title: Is buttermilk another term for sour milk or some part of sour milk?
provenance.paragraph_text:
Buttermilk is the byproduct of butter making.
Butter is made by agitating cream (-> the fatty part of milk) resulting in clumps of fat and a milky white liquid that contains nearly no fat and some protein. If the cream was soured before (either by aging or by inoculating the cream with lactobacillae), the buttermilk will also be sour. If the butter was made from unfermented cream, the buttermilk will be mild.
Uncultured buttermilk is rarely sold, even if butter is made commercially with regular cream, the resulting buttermilk is soured afterwards.
As buttermilk is made from a fraction of whole milk (the cream), you could say it’s a part of soured milk. I outlined the process of butter making in this answer, that should also help understanding buttermilk.
